Efficient Wireless Federated Learning with Partial Model Aggregation

Zhixiong Chen, , Wenqiang Yi, ,
Arumugam Nallanathan, , and Geoffrey Ye Li,  Zhixiong Chen, Wenqiang Yi, and Arumugam Nallanathan are with the School of Electronic Engineering and Computer Science, Queen Mary University of London, London, U.K. (emails: {zhixiong.chen, w.yi, a.nallanathan}@qmul.ac.uk).Geoffrey Ye Li is with the Faculty of Engineering, Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Imperial College London, England (e-mail: geoffrey.li@imperial.ac.uk).Part of this work has been accepted to IEEE International Conference on Communications (ICC), 2023 [1].
Abstract

The data heterogeneity across devices and the limited communication resources, e.g., bandwidth and energy, are two of the main bottlenecks for wireless federated learning (FL). To tackle these challenges, we first devise a novel FL framework with partial model aggregation (PMA). This approach aggregates the lower layers of neural networks, responsible for feature extraction, at the parameter server while keeping the upper layers, responsible for complex pattern recognition, at devices for personalization. The proposed PMA-FL is able to address the data heterogeneity and reduce the transmitted information in wireless channels. Then, we derive a convergence bound of the framework under a non-convex loss function setting to reveal the role of unbalanced data size in the learning performance. On this basis, we maximize the scheduled data size to minimize the global loss function through jointly optimize the device scheduling, bandwidth allocation, computation and communication time division policies with the assistance of Lyapunov optimization. Our analysis reveals that the optimal time division is achieved when the communication and computation parts of PMA-FL have the same power. We also develop a bisection method to solve the optimal bandwidth allocation policy and use the set expansion algorithm to address the device scheduling policy. Compared with the benchmark schemes, the proposed PMA-FL improves 3.13% and 11.8% accuracy on two typical datasets with heterogeneous data distribution settings, i.e., MINIST and CIFAR-10, respectively. In addition, the proposed joint dynamic device scheduling and resource management approach achieve slightly higher accuracy than the considered benchmarks, but they provide a satisfactory energy and time reduction: 29% energy or 20% time reduction on the MNIST; and 25% energy or 12.5% time reduction on the CIFAR-10.

Index Terms:
Device scheduling, federated Learning, Lyapunov optimization, resource management

I Introduction

Federated learning (FL) is a promising distributed learning approach for protecting data privacy. In FL, edge devices collaboratively train a model under the orchestration of a parameter server (PS), which only requires local learning models/gradients instead of local private data [2]. FL operations can be divided into two parts, namely the communication part and the computation part [3]. For the communication part, the learning performance is constrained by the limited communication resources, e.g., bandwidth and energy. For the computation part, the model accuracy is degraded by non-independent and identically distributed (non-IID) data samples. More specifically, the inadequate wireless resources hinder more devices devoted to the FL training process, thus negatively affecting the convergence speed and learning accuracy [4, 5]. Moreover, since the PS aggregates models learned from the different devices, the data heterogeneity presented on different devices may lead to weak generalization ability of the trained global model, even resulting in an unstable training process of FL [6]. Therefore, FL needs well-designed solutions to address these two challenges.

I-A Related Works

From the communication perspective, efficient resource management and device scheduling schemes can enable additional devices to participate in the FL process and thus enhancing learning performance. To this end, existing works focus on resource optimization [7, 8, 9, 10], device selection [11, 12, 13, 14], and alternating direction method of multipliers to reduce the communication rounds of training [15]. The energy-efficient workload partitioning scheme in [7] balances the computation between the central processing unit and graphics processing unit in the FL system. The time-sharing-based transmission scheme in [8] can improve the communication efficiency of FL. In [9], a sequential transmission scheme has been developed for global model aggregation. Based on this transmission scheme, the authors proposed a device heterogeneity-aware scheduling approach to maximize the number of scheduled data samples under energy constraints. The work in [10] introduced an energy-efficient transmission and computation resource allocation approach for energy consumption minimization of FL system under a latency constraint. The joint device scheduling and resource allocation policy in [11] maximizes the model accuracy in latency-constrained FL. The joint client selection and bandwidth allocation scheme in [12] maximizes the scheduled data samples under long-term client energy constraints. In [13], a gradient norm approximation method can assist the device scheduling for boosting the training performance in the over-the-air FL system. A joint learning, wireless resource allocation, and user selection problem has been investigated in [14] to minimize an FL loss function. Although these works have devised different device scheduling and resource management policies to facilitate FL, the joint optimization of communication and computation in FL has been rarely explored.

From the computation perspective, the emerging personalized FL techniques are promising to tackle the data heterogeneity-related challenges, which adapt the collaboratively learned global model for individual clients. Most personalized federated learning techniques involve two steps: 1) devices train a global model in a collaborative fashion, 2) each device personalizes the global model using its private data. Existing works toward this direction utilize various techniques to implement model personalization in the latter step, including multi-task learning [16], meta-learning [17], and model regularization [18]. More specifically, it has been shown in [16] that multi-task learning is a natural choice for building personalized federated models. However, the multi-task FL heavily relies on the full participation of devices in each round. The federated meta-learning algorithm in [17] can improve the model accuracy of FL, which maps the meta-training to the federated training process and meta-testing to FL personalization. A proximal term is introduced in [18] to limit the impact of local updates, achieving convergence stability and improving model generalization. However, the above techniques require more computation or memory resources than the conventional FL algorithms that solely train a global model, e.g., Federated Averaging (FedAvg) [19].

I-B Motivations and Contributions

Although the resource allocation and device scheduling schemes in [7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13, 14, 15] effectively alleviate the communication burden for FL in wireless networks, they are all operated by averaging local models for global aggregation and are hard to cope with the data heterogeneity nature of FL. In addition, the personalized FL algorithms in [16, 17, 18] require more computation or memory resources than the conventional weight averaging-based FL algorithms. Motivated by this, this work aims to devise an efficient FL approach that simultaneously tackles data heterogeneity and communication resource limitations for FL in wireless networks. Inspired by the success of centralized learning, different learning tasks often share the lower layers of neural networks responsible for feature extraction while the heterogeneity mainly focuses on the upper layers corresponding to complex pattern recognition[20, 21]. We propose a novel FL framework that partially aggregates local model parameters of the devices in the learning process to learn a shared feature extractor, while the label predictor part are localized at devices for personalization. This design effectively improves the learning performance of FL under heterogeneous local data distribution scenarios. In addition, in view of the devices’ limited wireless resources and energy budget, we devise a joint device scheduling, wireless bandwidth, and computation resources allocation scheme to improve the learning performance of FL in practical wireless networks. The main contributions of this paper are summarized as follows:

  • •

    To tackle the data heterogeneity across devices in the FL system, we devise a novel federated learning framework, namely partial model aggregation-FL (PMA-FL), in which devices only collaboratively train the lower layers of the neural networks while the upper layers are individually trained by each device for personalization. This design is able to reduce the data volumes in the transmission phase and improve the learning performance on heterogeneous local data distribution scenarios.

  • •

    To enable efficient FL in wireless networks, we minimize the global loss function while simultaneously considering devices’ long-term energy budget, bandwidth limitation, and latency constraints. However, it is intractable to minimize the global loss due to its inexplicit form. To this end, we theoretically characterize the convergence bound of the considered FL system with the general non-convex loss function setting, finding a new metric, termed scheduled data sample volume, which is in an explicit form for the device scheduling policy. The minimum global loss function can be obtained by maximizing this metric.

  • •

    To maximize the scheduled data sample volume, we formulate a joint device scheduling, wireless bandwidth allocation, and computation-communication-time division optimization problem, which is a mixed-integer nonlinear programming problem and is challenging to solve. We first decouple the long-term stochastic problem into a deterministic one in each communication round with the assistance of the Lyapunov optimization framework. Then, we derive the optimal solution for time division policies through convex optimization techniques, develop a bisection method to address the optimal bandwidth allocation policy, and use the set expansion algorithm to achieve the device scheduling policy.

  • •

    Experiments show that the proposed FL algorithm achieves faster convergence speed and higher model accuracies compared with the benchmark schemes, improving 3.13% and 11.8% accuracy on MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets, respectively. Moreover, the proposed joint device scheduling and resource management algorithm can reduce around 29% energy budget or 20% time budget and is able to achieve higher accuracies than the considered benchmarks on the MNIST dataset. On the CIFAR-10 dataset, the proposed algorithm can obtain slightly higher accuracies than the benchmark schemes and reduce the 25% energy budget or 12.5% time budget.

I-C Organization and Notations

The rest of this paper is organized as follows: In Section II, we introduce the FL system and learning cost, then formulate the global loss minimization problem. The convergence analysis and problem transformation are illustrated in Section III. The joint device schedule, wireless bandwidth allocation, and time division algorithm are developed in IV. Section V verifies the effectiveness of the proposed scheme by simulation. The conclusion is drawn in Section VI. For convenience, we use “=ΔsuperscriptΔ\buildrel\Delta\over{=}” to denote “is defined to be equal to”, |⋅|\left|\cdot\right| denote the size operation of a set, ∇(⋅)∇⋅\nabla(\cdot) denote gradient operator, ⟨⋅,⋅⟩⋅⋅\left\langle{\cdot,\cdot}\right\rangle denote inner product operator, and “∥⋅∥\left\|\cdot\right\|” denote the ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} norm throughout this paper. II System Model

After introducing the general FL system in this section, we will discuss FL with partial model aggregation (PMA), the computation cost, and the communication cost, and then formulate the problem.

II-A Federated Learning System

In this work, we consider a typical FL setting for supervised learning, consisting of one PS and K𝐾K devices indexed by 𝒦={1,2,⋯,K}𝒦12⋯𝐾\mathcal{K}=\left\{{1,2,\cdots,K}\right\}, as shown in Fig. 2. Each device k𝑘k (k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}) has a local dataset 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k} with Dk=|𝒟k|subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝒟𝑘D_{k}=\left|\mathcal{D}_{k}\right| data samples. Without loss of generality, we assume there is no overlapping for datasets from different devices, i.e., 𝒟k∩𝒟h=∅,(∀k,h∈𝒦)subscript𝒟𝑘subscript𝒟ℎfor-all𝑘ℎ𝒦\mathcal{D}_{k}\cap\mathcal{D}_{h}=\emptyset,(\forall k,h\in\mathcal{K}). Thus, the whole dataset, 𝒟=∪{𝒟k}k=1K𝒟superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑘1𝐾\mathcal{D}=\cup\left\{\mathcal{D}_{k}\right\}_{k=1}^{K}, is with total number of samples D=∑k=1KDk𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝐷𝑘D=\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{K}D_{k}.

Given a data sample (𝒙,𝒚)∈𝒟𝒙𝒚𝒟(\bm{x},\bm{y})\in\mathcal{D}, where 𝒙∈ℝd𝒙superscriptℝ𝑑\bm{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} represents the input feature vector of the sample, and 𝒚∈ℝ𝒚ℝ\bm{y}\in\mathbb{R} is the corresponding ground-truth label. Let 𝒛∈ℝp𝒛superscriptℝ𝑝\bm{z}\in\mathbb{R}^{p} be the latent feature space. The machine learning model parameterized by 𝒘=[𝒖,𝒗]𝒘𝒖𝒗\bm{w}=[\bm{u},\bm{v}] consists of two components: a feature extractor 𝒙→𝒛→𝒙𝒛\bm{x}\to\bm{z} parameterized by 𝒖𝒖\bm{u} and a predictor 𝒛→𝒚^→𝒛bold-^𝒚\bm{z}\to\bm{\hat{y}} parameterized by 𝒗𝒗\bm{v}. Let f​(𝒙,𝒚;𝒘)𝑓𝒙𝒚𝒘f(\bm{x},\bm{y};\bm{w}) denotes the sample-wise loss function, which quantifies the error between the ground-truth label, 𝒚𝒚\bm{y}, and the predicted output, 𝒚^bold-^𝒚\bm{\hat{y}}, based on model 𝒘𝒘\bm{w}. Thus, the local loss function at device k𝑘k, which measures the model error on its local dataset 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k}, is defined as

Fk​(𝒘k)=Fk​(𝒖k,𝒗k)=Δ1Dk​∑(𝒙,𝒚)∈𝒟kf​(𝒙,𝒚;𝒘k),subscript𝐹𝑘subscript𝒘𝑘subscript𝐹𝑘subscript𝒖𝑘subscript𝒗𝑘superscriptΔ1subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝒙𝒚subscript𝒟𝑘𝑓𝒙𝒚subscript𝒘𝑘\displaystyle F_{k}(\bm{w}_{k})=F_{k}(\bm{u}_{k},\bm{v}_{k})\buildrel\Delta\over{=}\frac{1}{D_{k}}\sum\nolimits_{(\bm{x},\bm{y})\in\mathcal{D}_{k}}{f(\bm{x},\bm{y};\bm{w}_{k})}, (1)

where 𝒘ksubscript𝒘𝑘\bm{w}_{k} denotes the model of device k𝑘k; 𝒖ksubscript𝒖𝑘\bm{u}_{k} and 𝒗ksubscript𝒗𝑘\bm{v}_{k} correspond to the feature extractor and predictor, respectively. Accordingly, the global loss function associated with all distributed local datasets is given by

F​(𝒘1,⋯,𝒘K)=Δ1D​∑k=1KDk​Fk​(𝒘k).superscriptΔ𝐹subscript𝒘1⋯subscript𝒘𝐾1𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝐹𝑘subscript𝒘𝑘\displaystyle F(\bm{w}_{1},\cdots,\bm{w}_{K})\buildrel\Delta\over{=}\frac{1}{D}\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{K}{D_{k}F_{k}(\bm{w}_{k})}. (2)

The federated learning process is done by solving the following problem

(3)

To preserve the data privacy of devices, the devices collaboratively learn (𝒘1,⋯,𝒘K)subscript𝒘1⋯subscript𝒘𝐾(\bm{w}_{1},\cdots,\bm{w}_{K}) by only uploading local learning models 𝒘k​(k∈𝒦)subscript𝒘𝑘𝑘𝒦\bm{w}_{k}(k\in\mathcal{K}) to the PS for periodical aggregation, instead of transmitting the raw training data.

II-B Federated Learning with Partial Model Aggregation

The main objective of the typical federated learning algorithms, such as the FedAvg [19], is to find an optimal shared global model 𝒘∗=𝒘k∗superscript𝒘superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑘\bm{w}^{*}=\bm{w}_{k}^{*} (∀k∈𝒦)for-all𝑘𝒦(\forall k\in\mathcal{K}) that minimizes the global loss function F​(𝒘1,⋯,𝒘K)𝐹subscript𝒘1⋯subscript𝒘𝐾F(\bm{w}_{1},\cdots,\bm{w}_{K}), as shown in Fig. 2(a). However, the data distributions among different devices in real-world FL systems are often heterogeneous, namely statistical heterogeneity. In the presence of statistical data heterogeneity, the local optimal models may drift significantly from each other, and thus solely optimizing for the global model’s accuracy leads to a poor generalization of each device.

Fortunately, the success of centralized learning in training multiple tasks or learning multiple classes simultaneously has shown that data often shares a global feature representation (i.e., 𝒖𝒖\bm{u}), while the statistical heterogeneity across devices or tasks is mainly located at the labels’ predictor (i.e., 𝒗𝒗\bm{v}) [20, 21]. Thus, this work proposes PMA in the FL training process instead of aggregating the entire model, as shown in Fig. 2(b). Specifically, devices who participate in the FL training process only upload the parameters of feature extractor 𝒖𝒖\bm{u} for global aggregation and the predictor 𝒗𝒗\bm{v} is localized for personalization. The learning process repeats the following steps until the model converges. The combination of the steps is referred to as a global round.

  • •

    Device Selection: The PS collects communication and computation information from each device and determines the set of scheduled devices in the current round, which is denoted by 𝑺tsubscript𝑺𝑡\bm{S}_{t}. Let αk,t∈{0,1}subscript𝛼𝑘𝑡01\alpha_{k,t}\in\{0,1\} denotes the scheduling indicator of device k𝑘k in round t𝑡t, where αk,t=1subscript𝛼𝑘𝑡1\alpha_{k,t}\!=\!1 indicates that device k𝑘k is scheduled in round t𝑡t, αk,t=0subscript𝛼𝑘𝑡0\alpha_{k,t}\!=\!0 otherwise. Thus, we have 𝑺t={k:αk,t=1,∀k∈𝒦}subscript𝑺𝑡conditional-set𝑘formulae-sequencesubscript𝛼𝑘𝑡1for-all𝑘𝒦\bm{S}_{t}\!=\!\{k:\alpha_{k,t}=1,\forall k\in\mathcal{K}\}.

  • •

    Global Feature Extractor Broadcast: In each round t𝑡t, the PS broadcasts the current latest global feature extractor 𝒖tsubscript𝒖𝑡\bm{u}_{t} to all scheduled devices.

  • •

    Local Model Training: All scheduled devices update their local models after receiving the global feature extractor 𝒖tsubscript𝒖𝑡\bm{u}_{t}. For device k𝑘k, its local feature extractor in round (t+1𝑡1t+1) is updated as

    𝒖k,t+1=𝒖t−αk,t​ηu​∇𝒖Fk​(𝒖t,𝒗k,t),subscript𝒖𝑘𝑡1subscript𝒖𝑡subscript𝛼𝑘𝑡subscript𝜂𝑢subscript∇𝒖subscript𝐹𝑘subscript𝒖𝑡subscript𝒗𝑘𝑡\bm{u}_{k,t+1}=\bm{u}_{t}-\alpha_{k,t}{\eta_{u}}{\nabla_{\bm{u}}}F_{k}(\bm{u}_{t},\bm{v}_{k,t}), (4)

    and its predictor is updated by

    𝒗k,t+1=𝒗k,t−αk,t​ηv​∇𝒗Fk​(𝒖t,𝒗k,t),subscript𝒗𝑘𝑡1subscript𝒗𝑘𝑡subscript𝛼𝑘𝑡subscript𝜂𝑣subscript∇𝒗subscript𝐹𝑘subscript𝒖𝑡subscript𝒗𝑘𝑡\bm{v}_{k,t+1}=\bm{v}_{k,t}-{\alpha_{k,t}}{\eta_{v}}{\nabla_{\bm{v}}}{F_{k}}(\bm{u}_{t},\bm{v}_{k,t}), (5)

    where ηusubscript𝜂𝑢\eta_{u} and ηvsubscript𝜂𝑣\eta_{v} represent the learning rate of feature extractor 𝒖𝒖\bm{u} and predictor 𝒗𝒗\bm{v}, respectively. For ease of presentation, we use 𝑽=(𝒗1,𝒗2,⋯,𝒗K)𝑽subscript𝒗1subscript𝒗2⋯subscript𝒗𝐾\bm{V}=(\bm{v}_{1},\bm{v}_{2},\cdots,\bm{v}_{K}) denotes all the devices’ predictors throughout this paper.

  • •

    Global Feature Extractor Aggregation: After finishing the local training, all scheduled devices upload their updated local feature extractors to the PS through wireless channels for aggregation. Specifically, the PS computes the global shared feature extractor as follows:

    𝒖t+1=∑k=1Kαk,t​Dk​𝒖k,t+1∑k=1Kαk,t​Dk.subscript𝒖𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝛼𝑘𝑡subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝒖𝑘𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝛼𝑘𝑡subscript𝐷𝑘\displaystyle\bm{u}_{t+1}=\frac{\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{K}\alpha_{k,t}D_{k}\bm{u}_{k,t+1}}{\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{K}\alpha_{k,t}D_{k}}. (6)

To better illustrate the benefits of partial sharing the model parameters, we provide an experiment on both MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets in Fig. 2, where the data distribution of each device is non-IID. Specifically, each device possesses at most two classes of data samples and participates in the training in each round. The MNIST dataset is trained by a 4-layers multi-layer perceptron (MLP) model, and the CIFAR-10 dataset is trained by a 5-layers convolutional neural network (CNN) model. The detailed configurations are shown in the experimental setting part in Section V. Fig. 2 shows that the MLP with only sharing the first two layers (n=2𝑛2n=2) in the training process obtains the highest accuracy and the CNN achieves the highest accuracy by aggregating the first four layers (n=4𝑛4n=4). One interesting result is that for both MLP and CNN, the global trained model (n=4𝑛4n=4 for the MLP and n=5𝑛5n=5 for the CNN) is less accurate than the local models of devices (n=0𝑛0n=0 for both the MLP and CNN) trained by their local datasets. Thus, aggregating the feature extractor with sufficient feature extracting ability in the training process is an efficient method to obtain better performance in the non-IID data distribution scenarios, instead of aggregating the entire model or solely training models on devices’ local datasets.

II-C Computation Cost

In each global round t𝑡t, the selected devices will perform local training after receiving the global feature extractor, 𝒖tsubscript𝒖𝑡\bm{u}_{t}, then uploading the trained local feature extractor parameters, 𝒖k,t+1subscript𝒖𝑘𝑡1\bm{u}_{k,t+1} (∀k∈𝑺tfor-all𝑘subscript𝑺𝑡\forall k\in\bm{S}_{t}), to the PS for aggregation. Let fk,tsubscript𝑓𝑘𝑡f_{k,t} denote the CPU frequency of device k𝑘k. Employing dynamic voltage and frequency scaling techniques [11], device k𝑘k can control the energy consumption for computation by adjusting the CPU frequency. Denote fk,maxsubscript𝑓𝑘f_{k,\max} the maximum CPU frequency of device k𝑘k. For any given machine learning model, the number of floating-point operations (FLOPs) required to one data sample for gradient calculation can be estimated, denoted by G𝐺G [23]. Let ζksubscript𝜁𝑘\zeta_{k} denote the number of CPU cycles required to process one floating-point operation, which depends on the CPU. Thus, the computation workload of one data sample at device k𝑘k is represented by Ck=ζk​Gsubscript𝐶𝑘subscript𝜁𝑘𝐺C_{k}=\zeta_{k}G. Based on the real measurement result in [24], energy consumption by devices is proportional to the square of their frequency. Thus, given the computation time restriction, Tk,tLsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑡LT_{k,t}^{\rm{L}}, the most energy efficient CPU frequency is fk,t=τ​Dk​CkTk,tLsubscript𝑓𝑘𝑡𝜏subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝐶𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑡Lf_{k,t}=\frac{\tau D_{k}C_{k}}{T_{k,t}^{\rm{L}}}, where τ𝜏\tau is the the number of local iterations. The corresponding energy consumption of device k𝑘k to perform local training is

Ek,tL=κ​τ​Dk​Ck​fk,t2=κ​τ3​Dk3​Ck3(Tk,tL)2,superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑡L𝜅𝜏subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝐶𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘𝑡2𝜅superscript𝜏3superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑘3superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑘3superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑡L2\displaystyle E_{k,t}^{\rm{L}}=\kappa\tau{D_{k}}C_{k}f_{k,t}^{2}=\frac{\kappa\tau^{3}D_{k}^{3}C_{k}^{3}}{(T_{k,t}^{\rm{L}})^{2}}, (7)

where κ𝜅\kappa denotes the devices’ energy coefficient that hinges on chip architecture. Since the CPU frequency of device k𝑘k is restricted by fk,maxsubscript𝑓𝑘f_{k,\max}, the computation time should satisfy

Tk,tL≥τ​Dk​Ckfk,max.superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑡L𝜏subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝐶𝑘subscript𝑓𝑘T_{k,t}^{\rm{L}}\geq\frac{\tau D_{k}C_{k}}{f_{k,\max}}. (8)

In the above discussion, we have ignored the global feature extractor aggregation cost, because the PS usually has strong computation capability with negligible aggregation delay.

II-D Communication Cost

The frequency-division multiple access (FDMA) technique is employed in the FL system with a total available bandwidth of B𝐵B Hz for devices to upload their local feature extractors 𝒖k,tsubscript𝒖𝑘𝑡\bm{u}_{k,t}. Let θk,tsubscript𝜃𝑘𝑡\theta_{k,t} (0≤θk,t≤10subscript𝜃𝑘𝑡10\leq\theta_{k,t}\leq 1) represent the proportion of wireless channel bandwidth allocated to device k𝑘k in round t𝑡t and pk,tsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑡p_{k,t} denote the uplink transmission power of device k𝑘k (k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}). We assume that the channel gain, hk,tsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡h_{k,t}, between device k𝑘k and the PS remains unchanged within one round but varies independently and identically over rounds. Consequently, the achievable uplink rates for device k𝑘k in round t𝑡t can be characterized by Shannon capacity, i.e., rk,t=θk,t​B​log⁡(1+pk,t​hk,tθk,t​B​N0)subscript𝑟𝑘𝑡subscript𝜃𝑘𝑡𝐵1subscript𝑝𝑘𝑡subscriptℎ𝑘𝑡subscript𝜃𝑘𝑡𝐵subscript𝑁0r_{k,t}=\theta_{k,t}B\log(1+\frac{p_{k,t}h_{k,t}}{{\theta_{k,t}B{N_{0}}}}), where N0subscript𝑁0N_{0} is the power density of noise. Denote Q𝑄Q by the data size of feature extractor (𝒖k,t,∀k∈𝒦,∀tformulae-sequencesubscript𝒖𝑘𝑡for-all𝑘𝒦for-all𝑡\bm{u}_{k,t},\forall k\in\mathcal{K},\forall t). Given the maximum communication time Tk,tUsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑡UT_{k,t}^{\rm{U}}, the most energy efficient transmission method is rk,t=QTk,tUsubscript𝑟𝑘𝑡𝑄superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑡Ur_{k,t}=\frac{Q}{T_{k,t}^{\rm{U}}} [25]. Thus, the transmit power is

pk,t=θk,t​B​N0hk,t​(2Qθk,t​B​Tk,tU−1).subscript𝑝𝑘𝑡subscript𝜃𝑘𝑡𝐵subscript𝑁0subscriptℎ𝑘𝑡superscript2𝑄subscript𝜃𝑘𝑡𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑡U1{p_{k,t}}=\frac{\theta_{k,t}BN_{0}}{h_{k,t}}\Big{(}2^{\frac{Q}{\theta_{k,t}BT_{k,t}^{\rm{U}}}}-1\Big{)}. (9)

The corresponding energy consumption is Ek,tU=pk,t​Tk,tUsuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑡Usubscript𝑝𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑡UE_{k,t}^{\rm{U}}={p_{k,t}}T_{k,t}^{\rm{U}}. Thus, the total energy consumption of device k𝑘k in round t𝑡t for both computation and communication is Ek,t=Ek,tL+Ek,tUsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑡Lsuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑡UE_{k,t}=E_{k,t}^{\rm{L}}+E_{k,t}^{\rm{U}}. Let pk,maxsubscript𝑝𝑘p_{k,\max} denote the maximum transmit power of device k𝑘k, then 0≤pk,t≤pk,max0subscript𝑝𝑘𝑡subscript𝑝𝑘0\leq p_{k,t}\leq p_{k,\max}. Thus, the communication time for device k𝑘k uploading its local feature extractor should satisfy

Tk,tU≥Qθk,t​B​log⁡(1+pk,max​hk,tθk,t​B​N0).superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑡U𝑄subscript𝜃𝑘𝑡𝐵1subscript𝑝𝑘subscriptℎ𝑘𝑡subscript𝜃𝑘𝑡𝐵subscript𝑁0T_{k,t}^{\rm{U}}\geq\frac{Q}{\theta_{k,t}B\log\Big{(}{1+\frac{{{p_{k,\max}}{h_{k,t}}}}{{\theta_{k,t}B{N_{0}}}}}\Big{)}}. (10)

Similar to many existing works as in [12, 13, 8], we ignore the global feature extractor broadcasting cost and mainly focus on the performance bottleneck of the battery and communication-constrained edge devices because the PS usually supplied by the grid is energy-sufficient. Moreover, the broadcasting process occupies the entire bandwidth and the transmit power of the PS is usually large, the transmission delay is negligible.

II-E Problem Formulation

The objective of this work is to minimize the expected global loss 𝔼​[F​(𝒖T,𝑽T)]𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript𝒖𝑇subscript𝑽𝑇\mathbb{E}[F(\bm{u}_{T},\bm{V}_{T})] after T𝑇T rounds under the energy budget constraints of devices. To this end, we jointly optimize the device scheduling, bandwidth allocation, computation time, and communication time allocation policy. Denote 𝜽t=(θ1,t,θ2,t,⋯,θK,t)subscript𝜽𝑡subscript𝜃1𝑡subscript𝜃2𝑡⋯subscript𝜃𝐾𝑡\bm{\theta}_{t}=(\theta_{1,t},\theta_{2,t},\cdots,\theta_{K,t}) as the proportions of the overall wireless bandwidth allocated to different devices in round t𝑡t. Let 𝑻tL=(T1,tL,T2,tL,⋯,TK,tL)superscriptsubscript𝑻𝑡Lsuperscriptsubscript𝑇1𝑡Lsuperscriptsubscript𝑇2𝑡L⋯superscriptsubscript𝑇𝐾𝑡L\bm{T}_{t}^{\rm{L}}=(T_{1,t}^{\rm{L}},T_{2,t}^{\rm{L}},\cdots,T_{K,t}^{\rm{L}}) and 𝑻tU=(T1,tU,T2,tU,⋯,TK,tU)superscriptsubscript𝑻𝑡Usuperscriptsubscript𝑇1𝑡Usuperscriptsubscript𝑇2𝑡U⋯superscriptsubscript𝑇𝐾𝑡U\bm{T}_{t}^{\rm{U}}=(T_{1,t}^{\rm{U}},T_{2,t}^{\rm{U}},\cdots,T_{K,t}^{\rm{U}}) denote the computation time and communication time for all devices in round t𝑡t, respectively. We formulate the problem as follows:

𝒫::𝒫absent\displaystyle\mathcal{P}:~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{} min{𝑺t,𝜽t,𝑻tL,𝑻tU,}t=0T−1⁡𝔼​[F​(𝒖T,𝑽T)]\displaystyle\min_{\left\{\bm{S}_{t},\bm{\theta}_{t},\bm{T}_{t}^{\rm{L}},\bm{T}_{t}^{\text{U}},\right\}_{t=0}^{T-1}}~{}\mathbb{E}\left[F(\bm{u}_{T},\bm{V}_{T})\right] (11)
s. t. (8),(10),810\displaystyle(\text{\ref{eq:time_ltcons}}),(\text{\ref{eq:time_utcons}}), (11a)
∑t=0T−1Ek,t≤Ek,∀k∈𝒦,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1subscript𝐸𝑘𝑡subscript𝐸𝑘for-all𝑘𝒦\displaystyle\sum\nolimits_{t=0}^{T-1}{{E_{k,t}}\leq}{E_{k}},\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, (11b)
αk,t∈{0,1},∀k∈𝒦,∀t.formulae-sequencesubscript𝛼𝑘𝑡01for-all𝑘𝒦for-all𝑡\displaystyle\alpha_{k,t}\in\left\{{0,1}\right\},\forall k\in\mathcal{K},\forall t. (11c)
∑k=1Kθk,t≤1,∀t,superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝜃𝑘𝑡1for-all𝑡\displaystyle\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{K}\theta_{k,t}\leq 1,\forall t, (11d)
0≤θk,t≤1,∀k∈𝒦,∀t,formulae-sequence0subscript𝜃𝑘𝑡1for-all𝑘𝒦for-all𝑡\displaystyle 0\leq\theta_{k,t}\leq 1,\forall k\in\mathcal{K},\forall t, (11e)
Tk,tL+Tk,tU≤Tmax,∀k∈𝒦,∀t,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑡Lsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑡Usubscript𝑇for-all𝑘𝒦for-all𝑡\displaystyle T_{k,t}^{\rm{L}}+T_{k,t}^{\rm{U}}\leq{T_{\max}},\forall k\in\mathcal{K},\forall t, (11f)

In problem 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}, (11a) restricts the computation and communication time. (11b) indicates that for each device, the total energy consumption for both computation and communication over T𝑇T global rounds cannot exceed its given budget. (11c) indicates that which devices are scheduled in each round. (11d) assures that the wireless bandwidth resource allocated to all devices would not exceed the total available bandwidth resource. (11e) imposes restrictions on the wireless bandwidth resource allocated to each device. (11f) stipulates that the completion time for the participating devices in one round cannot exceed its maximum allowable delay Tmaxsubscript𝑇T_{\max}.

Problem 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} involves a combinatorial optimization over the multi-dimensional discrete and continuous space, which is challenging to solve. Two major challenges of solving problem 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} are:

  1. 1)

    Inexplicit form of the objective function: Since the evolutions of the feature extractor 𝒖tsubscript𝒖𝑡\bm{u}_{t} and predictors 𝒗k,tsubscript𝒗𝑘𝑡\bm{v}_{k,t} are complex in the training process, it is intractable to solve the close-form expression of 𝔼​[F​(𝒖T,𝑽T)]𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript𝒖𝑇subscript𝑽𝑇\mathbb{E}\left[F(\bm{u}_{T},\bm{V}_{T})\right].

  2. 2)

    Unknown future information: The optimal solution of 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} requires exact channel state and devices’ energy status information of all rounds at the beginning of training, which is impractical in real-world systems.

To tackle these challenges, we first analyze the convergence bound of the considered PMA-FL algorithm and transform problem 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} into optimizing the convergence bound.

III Convergence Analysis and Problem Transformation

In this section, we start with convergence analysis of the considered PMA-FL algorithm to find a metric, i.e., scheduled data size, which is in an explicit form with respect to the device schedule. Then, we transform problem 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} into maximizing this metric, so as to obtain the minimum global loss function when the FL converges. To address the challenge brought by the long-term energy constraint, we further transform the problem into a deterministic problem in each communication round by characterizing the Lyapunov drift-plus-penalty ratio function with the assistance of the Lyapunov optimization framework.

III-A Convergence Anaysis

We now investigate the convergence behaviour of the federated learning algorithm with partial model aggregation. To facilitate analysis, we make the following assumptions on the loss functions F​(⋅)𝐹⋅F(\cdot).

Assumption 1.

(Lipschitz continuous): All loss function Fk​(𝒖,𝒗k)subscript𝐹𝑘𝒖subscript𝒗𝑘{F_{k}}(\bm{u},\bm{v}_{k}) are continuously differentiable with respect to 𝒖𝒖\bm{u} and 𝒗ksubscript𝒗𝑘\bm{v}_{k}, and there exist constants L𝒖subscript𝐿𝒖L_{\bm{u}}, L𝒗subscript𝐿𝒗L_{\bm{v}}, L𝒖​𝒗subscript𝐿𝒖𝒗L_{\bm{uv}}, and L𝒗​𝒖subscript𝐿𝒗𝒖L_{\bm{vu}} such that for each Fk​(𝒖,𝒗k)subscript𝐹𝑘𝒖subscript𝒗𝑘{F_{k}}(\bm{u},\bm{v}_{k}) (k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}),

    ∇𝒖Fk​(𝒖,𝒗k)subscript∇𝒖subscript𝐹𝑘𝒖subscript𝒗𝑘\nabla_{\bm{u}}{F_{k}}(\bm{u},{\bm{v}_{k}}) is L𝒖subscript𝐿𝒖L_{\bm{u}}-Lipschitz continuous with 𝒖𝒖\bm{u} and L𝒖​𝒗subscript𝐿𝒖𝒗L_{\bm{uv}}-Lipschitz continuous with 𝒗ksubscript𝒗𝑘\bm{v}_{k}, that is,

    ‖∇𝒖Fk​(𝒖,𝒗k)−∇𝒖Fk​(𝒖′,𝒗k)‖≤L𝒖​‖𝒖−𝒖′‖,normsubscript∇𝒖subscript𝐹𝑘𝒖subscript𝒗𝑘subscript∇𝒖subscript𝐹𝑘superscript𝒖′subscript𝒗𝑘subscript𝐿𝒖norm𝒖superscript𝒖′\displaystyle\left\|{\nabla_{\bm{u}}{F_{k}}(\bm{u},{\bm{v}_{k}})\!-\!\nabla_{\bm{u}}{F_{k}}(\bm{u}^{\prime},\bm{v}_{k})}\right\|\leq{L_{\bm{u}}}\left\|\bm{u}\!-\!\bm{u}^{\prime}\right\|, (12)

Assumption 2.

(Partial Gradient Diversity): There exist δ≥0𝛿0\delta\geq 0 and ρ≥0𝜌0\rho\geq 0 such that for all 𝒖𝒖\bm{u} and 𝑽𝑽\bm{V}, i.e.,

‖∇𝒖Fk​(𝒖,𝒗k)‖2≤δ2+ρ2​‖∇𝒖F​(𝒖,𝑽)‖2.superscriptnormsubscript∇𝒖subscript𝐹𝑘𝒖subscript𝒗𝑘2superscript𝛿2superscript𝜌2superscriptnormsubscript∇𝒖𝐹𝒖𝑽2\displaystyle{\left\|{\nabla_{\bm{u}}{F_{k}}(\bm{u},\bm{v}_{k})}\right\|^{2}}\leq\delta^{2}+\rho^{2}{\left\|{\nabla_{\bm{u}}F(\bm{u},\bm{V})}\right\|^{2}}. (14)

Assumption 1 is not stringent, which is satisfied by most deep neural networks. In fact, the convolution layer, linear layer, and some nonlinear activation functions (e.g., Sigmoid and tanh have already proved to be Lipschitz [26]. Based on [26], a deep neural network defined by a composition of functions is a Lipschitz neural network if the functions in all layers are Lipschitz. Thus, most neural networks have the Lipschitz continuous gradients. Assumption 2 is widely used in the convergence analysis in FL algorithms, e.g., [14, 27]. To begin with, we first derive a key lemma, proved in Appendix LABEL:App:A1, to assist our analysis as follows:

Lemma 1.

Let Assumption 1 holds, we have

Based on Lemma 1, we derive the one-round global loss reduction bound in Appendix LABEL:App:A2, which is summarized in the following Lemma.

According to Lemma 2, one can find that the number of data samples scheduled in each round, i.e., ∑k=1Kαk,t​Dksuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝛼𝑘𝑡subscript𝐷𝑘\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{K}{{\alpha_{k,t}}{D_{k}}}, is the main contributor to the convergence rate of training. Based on Lemma 2, we derive the convergence performance of the proposed PMA-FL algorithm after T𝑇T training rounds in the following theorem, proved in Appendix LABEL:App:A3.

𝔼​[F​(𝒖T,𝑽T)−F​(𝒖∗,𝑽∗)]≤(𝔼​[F​(𝒖0,𝑽0)−F​(𝒖∗,𝑽∗)])​∏t=0T−1At+∑t=0T−12​ηu​δ2D2​(D−∑k=1Kαk,t​Dk)2​∏j=t+1T−1Aj,𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript𝒖𝑇subscript𝑽𝑇𝐹superscript𝒖superscript𝑽𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript𝒖0subscript𝑽0𝐹superscript𝒖superscript𝑽superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑡0𝑇1subscript𝐴𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇12subscript𝜂𝑢superscript𝛿2superscript𝐷2superscript𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝛼𝑘𝑡subscript𝐷𝑘2superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑗𝑡1𝑇1subscript𝐴𝑗\mathbb{E}\left[F(\bm{u}_{T},\bm{V}_{T})-F(\bm{u}^{*},\bm{V}^{*})\right]\leq\Big{(}\mathbb{E}\left[F(\bm{u}_{0},\bm{V}_{0})-F(\bm{u}^{*},\bm{V}^{*})\right]\Big{)}\mathop{\prod}\nolimits_{t=0}^{T-1}{A_{t}}\\ +\sum\nolimits_{t=0}^{T-1}\frac{2\eta_{u}\delta^{2}}{D^{2}}\Big{(}{D-\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{K}\alpha_{k,t}D_{k}}\Big{)}^{2}\mathop{\prod}\nolimits_{j=t+1}^{T-1}{A_{j}}, (17)

where At=1+ηu​L𝐮​(4D2​(D−∑k=1Kαk,t​Dk)2​ρ2−1)subscript𝐴𝑡1subscript𝜂𝑢subscript𝐿𝐮4superscript𝐷2superscript𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝛼𝑘𝑡subscript𝐷𝑘2superscript𝜌21A_{t}=1+\eta_{u}L_{\bm{u}}(\frac{4}{D^{2}}{\big{(}D-\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{K}\alpha_{k,t}D_{k}\big{)}^{2}}\rho^{2}-1).

From Theorem 1, we can conclude when t𝑡t trends to infinity with 0<ρ<120𝜌120<\rho<\frac{1}{2} (i.e., 0<At<10subscript𝐴𝑡10<A_{t}<1): 1) The FL training converges since ∏t=0T−1Atsuperscriptsubscriptproduct𝑡0𝑇1subscript𝐴𝑡\prod\nolimits_{t=0}^{T-1}{A_{t}} turns to 0 as T𝑇T increases, resulting in the first term in the right-hand side (RHS) of (17) converges to zero and the second term in the RHS of (17) approaches to be fixed. 2) A gap, i.e., the second term in the RHS of (17), exists between F​(𝒖T,𝑽T)𝐹subscript𝒖𝑇subscript𝑽𝑇F(\bm{u}_{T},\bm{V}_{T}) and F​(𝒖∗,𝑽∗)𝐹superscript𝒖superscript𝑽F(\bm{u}^{*},\bm{V}^{*}). Particularly, Atsubscript𝐴𝑡A_{t} and the second term in the RHS of (17) affect the convergence speed and learning accuracy, respectively. A small Atsubscript𝐴𝑡A_{t} induces a fast learning speed, and a small ∑t=0T−12​ηu​δ2D2​(D−∑k=1Kαk,t​Dk)2​∏j=t+1T−1Ajsuperscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇12subscript𝜂𝑢superscript𝛿2superscript𝐷2superscript𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝛼𝑘𝑡subscript𝐷𝑘2superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑗𝑡1𝑇1subscript𝐴𝑗\sum\nolimits_{t=0}^{T-1}\frac{2\eta_{u}\delta^{2}}{D^{2}}(D-\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{K}\alpha_{k,t}D_{k})^{2}\mathop{\prod}\nolimits_{j=t+1}^{T-1}{A_{j}} results in a small loss function and high learning accuracy. Increasing ∑k=1Kαk,t​Dksuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝛼𝑘𝑡subscript𝐷𝑘\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{K}\alpha_{k,t}D_{k} in each round helps ∏t=0T−1Atsuperscriptsubscriptproduct𝑡0𝑇1subscript𝐴𝑡\prod\nolimits_{t=0}^{T-1}{A_{t}} approach 0 faster and decreases the second term in the RHS of (17). These observations motivate us to maximize ∑k=1Kαk,t​Dksuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝛼𝑘𝑡subscript𝐷𝑘\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{K}\alpha_{k,t}D_{k} in each round to improve the learning performance of PMA-FL. Note that, Theorem 1 reveals the impact of unbalanced data on the convergence performance of PMA-FL and builds the bridge between the scheduled data samples maximization and the global loss minimization from a theoretical perspective.

III-B Problem Transformation

Motivated by Theorem 1, we maximize the overall scheduled data size, i.e., ∑t=0T−1∑k=1Kαk,t​Dksuperscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝛼𝑘𝑡subscript𝐷𝑘\sum\nolimits_{t=0}^{T-1}\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{K}{\alpha_{k,t}}D_{k}, for the global loss function minimization. Thus, we transform problem 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} into the following one.

𝒫1:max{𝑺t,𝑻tL,𝑻tU,𝜽t}t=0T−1:subscript𝒫1subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑺𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑻𝑡Lsuperscriptsubscript𝑻𝑡Usubscript𝜽𝑡𝑡0𝑇1\displaystyle\mathcal{P}_{1}:~{}\max_{\left\{\bm{S}_{t},\bm{T}_{t}^{\rm{L}},\bm{T}_{t}^{\text{U}},\bm{\theta}_{t}\right\}_{t=0}^{T-1}}~{} ∑t=0T−1∑k=1Kαk,t​Dksuperscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝛼𝑘𝑡subscript𝐷𝑘\displaystyle\sum\nolimits_{t=0}^{T-1}\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{K}{\alpha_{k,t}}{D_{k}} (18)
s. t. (8),(10),(11b),(11c),(11d),(11e),(11f).81011b11c11d11e11f\displaystyle(\text{\ref{eq:time_ltcons}}),(\text{\ref{eq:time_utcons}}),(\text{\ref{cons:P_2}}),(\text{\ref{cons:P_3}}),(\text{\ref{cons:P_4}}),(\text{\ref{cons:P_5}}),(\text{\ref{cons:P_6}}).

Problem 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1} is difficult to solve due to the long-term energy constraint and the unknown future information about channel condition for devices. To enable online dynamic scheduling for devices, we construct a virtual queue qk​(t)subscript𝑞𝑘𝑡q_{k}(t) for each device k𝑘k to indicate the gap between the cumulative energy consumption till round t𝑡t and the budget, evolving according to

qk​(t+1)=max⁡{qk​(t)+αk,t​Ek,t−EkT,0},subscript𝑞𝑘𝑡1subscript𝑞𝑘𝑡subscript𝛼𝑘𝑡subscript𝐸𝑘𝑡subscript𝐸𝑘𝑇0\displaystyle q_{k}(t+1)=\max\left\{q_{k}(t)+\alpha_{k,t}E_{k,t}-\frac{E_{k}}{T},0\right\}, (19)

with an initial value qk​(0)=0subscript𝑞𝑘00{q_{k}}(0)=0 for all devices. Inspired by the drift-plus-penalty algorithm of Lyapunov optimization [28], the online scheduling aims to solve the following problem,

𝒫2:min{𝑺t,𝑻tL,𝑻tU,𝜽t}:subscript𝒫2subscriptsubscript𝑺𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑻𝑡Lsuperscriptsubscript𝑻𝑡Usubscript𝜽𝑡\displaystyle\mathcal{P}_{2}:\min_{\left\{\bm{S}_{t},\bm{T}_{t}^{\rm{L}},\bm{T}_{t}^{\text{U}},\bm{\theta}_{t}\right\}} −V​∑k=1Kαk,t​Dk+∑k=1Kqk​(t)​αk,t​Ek,t𝑉superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝛼𝑘𝑡subscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑞𝑘𝑡subscript𝛼𝑘𝑡subscript𝐸𝑘𝑡\displaystyle-V\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{K}{\alpha_{k,t}}{D_{k}}+\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{K}{q_{k}}(t){\alpha_{k,t}}E_{k,t} (20)
s. t. (8),(10),(11c),(11d),(11e),(11f).81011c11d11e11f\displaystyle(\text{\ref{eq:time_ltcons}}),(\text{\ref{eq:time_utcons}}),(\text{\ref{cons:P_3}}),(\text{\ref{cons:P_4}}),(\text{\ref{cons:P_5}}),(\text{\ref{cons:P_6}}).

where V≥0𝑉0V\geq 0 is an adjustable weight parameter to balance scheduled data size and energy consumption. A large V𝑉V indicates that the optimization objective emphasizes more on the scheduled data size for improving the learning performance and less on energy consumption minimization, and vice versa.

IV Energy-Efficient Dynamic Device Scheduling and Resource Management

In this section, we solve the deterministic combinatorial problems 𝒫2subscript𝒫2\mathcal{P}_{2} in each communication round. We first exploit the dependences among 𝑺tsubscript𝑺𝑡\bm{S}_{t}, 𝜽tsubscript𝜽𝑡\bm{\theta}_{t}, 𝑻tLsuperscriptsubscript𝑻𝑡L\bm{T}_{t}^{\rm{L}}, and 𝑻tUsuperscriptsubscript𝑻𝑡U\bm{T}_{t}^{\rm{U}} in problem 𝒫2subscript𝒫2\mathcal{P}_{2} and transform it into an equivalent problem that joint optimizing 𝑺tsubscript𝑺𝑡\bm{S}_{t}, 𝜽tsubscript𝜽𝑡\bm{\theta}_{t}, and 𝑻tLsuperscriptsubscript𝑻𝑡L\bm{T}_{t}^{\rm{L}}. Then we decompose it into three sub-problems and deploy an alternative optimization technique to obtain its optimal solution. For the convenience of analysis, we rewrite the local feature extractor uploading energy consumption as

Ek,tU=pk,t​Tk,tU=θk,t​B​N0​Tk,tUhk,t​(2Qθk,t​B​Tk,tU−1),superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑡Usubscript𝑝𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑡Usubscript𝜃𝑘𝑡𝐵subscript𝑁0superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑡Usubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡superscript2𝑄subscript𝜃𝑘𝑡𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑡U1\displaystyle E_{k,t}^{\rm{U}}={p_{k,t}}T_{k,t}^{\rm{U}}=\frac{\theta_{k,t}BN_{0}T_{k,t}^{\rm{U}}}{h_{k,t}}\Big{(}2^{\frac{Q}{\theta_{k,t}BT_{k,t}^{\rm{U}}}}-1\Big{)}, (21)

which is a non-increasing function with respect to Tk,tUsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑡UT_{k,t}^{\rm{U}}. Thus, by taking into account the constraint (11f), the optimal communication time satisfies Tk,tU=Tmax−Tk,tLsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑡Usubscript𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑡LT_{k,t}^{\rm{U}}={T_{\max}}-T_{k,t}^{\rm{L}}. Based on this, we can simplify problem 𝒫2subscript𝒫2\mathcal{P}_{2} as the following equivalent problem,

𝒫3:min{𝑺t,𝜽t,𝑻tL}:subscript𝒫3subscriptsubscript𝑺𝑡subscript𝜽𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑻𝑡L\displaystyle\mathcal{P}_{3}:\min_{\left\{\bm{S}_{t},\bm{\theta}_{t},\bm{T}_{t}^{\rm{L}}\right\}} −V​∑k=1Kαk,t​Dk+∑k=1Kqk​(t)​αk,t​Ek,t𝑉superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝛼𝑘𝑡subscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑞𝑘𝑡subscript𝛼𝑘𝑡subscript𝐸𝑘𝑡\displaystyle-V\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{K}{\alpha_{k,t}}{D_{k}}+\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{K}{q_{k}}(t){\alpha_{k,t}}E_{k,t} (22)
s. t. (11c),(11d),(11e),11c11d11e\displaystyle(\text{\ref{cons:P_3}}),(\text{\ref{cons:P_4}}),(\text{\ref{cons:P_5}}),
τ​Dk​Ck/fk,max≤Tk,tL≤Tmax−Q/rk,tmax​(θk,t),𝜏subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝐶𝑘subscript𝑓𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑡Lsubscript𝑇𝑄superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑘𝑡subscript𝜃𝑘𝑡\displaystyle\tau D_{k}C_{k}/f_{k,\max}\leq T_{k,t}^{\rm{L}}\leq{T_{\max}}-Q/r_{k,t}^{\max}(\theta_{k,t}), (22a)

However, problem 𝒫3subscript𝒫3\mathcal{P}_{3} is a mixed integer non-linear programming problem, which is still difficult to solve. In the below, we decompose it into three sub-problems and solve them one by one.

IV-A Local Training Time Allocation

For any given device scheduling policy 𝑺tsubscript𝑺𝑡\bm{S}_{t} and bandwidth allocation strategy 𝜽tsubscript𝜽𝑡\bm{\theta}_{t}, we can decompose the computation time allocation problem as follows,

𝒫4:min𝑻tL:subscript𝒫4subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑻𝑡L\displaystyle\mathcal{P}_{4}:\min_{\bm{T}_{t}^{\rm{L}}}~{}~{}~{} ∑k∈𝑺tqk​(t)​Ek,tsubscript𝑘subscript𝑺𝑡subscript𝑞𝑘𝑡subscript𝐸𝑘𝑡\displaystyle~{}~{}\sum\nolimits_{k\in\bm{S}_{t}}q_{k}(t)E_{k,t} (24)
s. t. (22a).22a\displaystyle(\text{\ref{cons:P3_1}}).

We can prove that 𝒫4subscript𝒫4\mathcal{P}_{4} is convex, and obtain its optimal solution as summarized in Lemma 3, proved in Appendix LABEL:App:A4.

Lemma 3.

Problem 𝒫4subscript𝒫4\mathcal{P}_{4} is a convex problem and its optimal solution is given as

Tk,tL,∗={τ​Dk​Ckfk,max,Tk,tL,0≤τ​Dk​Ckfk,max,Tmax−Qrk,tmax​(θk,t),Tk,tL,0≥Tmax−Qrk,tmax​(θk,t),Tk,tL,0,otherwise.superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑡Lcases𝜏subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝐶𝑘subscript𝑓𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑡L0𝜏subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝐶𝑘subscript𝑓𝑘missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionsubscript𝑇𝑄superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑘𝑡subscript𝜃𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑡L0subscript𝑇𝑄superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑘𝑡subscript𝜃𝑘𝑡missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑡L0otherwisemissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpression\displaystyle T_{k,t}^{\rm{L},*}=\left\{{\begin{array}[]{*{20}{c}}{\frac{\tau D_{k}C_{k}}{f_{k,\max}},}&{T_{k,t}^{\rm{L},0}\leq\frac{\tau D_{k}C_{k}}{f_{k,\max}},}\\ {{T_{\max}}-\frac{Q}{{r_{k,t}^{\max}(\theta_{k,t})}},}&{T_{k,t}^{\rm{L},0}\geq{T_{\max}}-\frac{Q}{{r_{k,t}^{\max}(\theta_{k,t})}},}\\ {T_{k,t}^{\rm{L},0}},&{\rm{otherwise}.}\end{array}}\right. (28)

where Tk,tL,0superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑡L0T_{k,t}^{\rm{L},0} satisfies the equality ∂Ek,t∂Tk,tL,0=0subscript𝐸𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑡L00\frac{\partial E_{k,t}}{\partial T_{k,t}^{\rm{L},0}}=0.

In fact, constraint (22a) imposes restrictions on the maximum frequency and transmit power and is usually inactive in practical system design because this usually can be satisfied by modifying the minimum required latency constraint, Tmaxsubscript𝑇T_{\max}, and bandwidth B𝐵B. Thus, we have the following remark.

Remark 1.

In general, the optimal computation time satisfy Tk,tL,∗=Tk,tL,0superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑡Lsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑡L0T_{k,t}^{\rm{L},*}=T_{k,t}^{\rm{L},0}, which is equivalent to ∂Ek,tL∂Tk,tL=∂Ek,tU∂TkUsuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑡Lsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑡Lsuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑡Usuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘U\frac{\partial E_{k,t}^{\rm{L}}}{\partial T_{k,t}^{\rm{L}}}=\frac{\partial E_{k,t}^{\rm{U}}}{\partial T_{k}^{\rm{U}}}. In other words, the computation time allocation policy is optimal when the power of local training equals that of wireless communication.

IV-B Wireless Bandwidth Allocation

For ease of presentation, we define an auxiliary function for each device k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} as follows:

gk​(θk,t)=exp⁡(Q​ln⁡2θk,t​B​(Tmax−Tk,tL))−1.subscript𝑔𝑘subscript𝜃𝑘𝑡𝑄2subscript𝜃𝑘𝑡𝐵subscript𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑡L1\displaystyle g_{k}(\theta_{k,t})=\exp\bigg{(}\frac{Q\ln 2}{\theta_{k,t}B(T_{\max}-T_{k,t}^{\rm{L}})}\bigg{)}-1. (29)

For any given computation time allocation decision 𝑻tLsuperscriptsubscript𝑻𝑡L\bm{T}_{t}^{\rm{L}} and device scheduling policy 𝑺tsubscript𝑺𝑡\bm{S}_{t}, the wireless bandwidth allocation problem can be separated as,

𝒫5:min𝜽t:subscript𝒫5subscriptsubscript𝜽𝑡\displaystyle\mathcal{P}_{5}:\min_{\bm{\theta}_{t}} h​(𝜽t)ℎsubscript𝜽𝑡\displaystyle~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}h(\bm{\theta}_{t}) (30)
s. t. (11d),(11e),11d11e\displaystyle(\text{\ref{cons:P_4}}),(\text{\ref{cons:P_5}}),
Q/(Tmax−Tk,tL)≤rk,tmax​(θk,t),𝑄subscript𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑡Lsuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑘𝑡subscript𝜃𝑘𝑡\displaystyle Q/(T_{\max}-T_{k,t}^{\rm{L}})\leq r_{k,t}^{\max}(\theta_{k,t}), (30a)

where

h​(𝜽t)=∑k∈𝑺tθk,t​N0​B​qk​(t)​(Tmax−Tk,tL)hk,t​gk​(θk,t).ℎsubscript𝜽𝑡subscript𝑘subscript𝑺𝑡subscript𝜃𝑘𝑡subscript𝑁0𝐵subscript𝑞𝑘𝑡subscript𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑡Lsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡subscript𝑔𝑘subscript𝜃𝑘𝑡\displaystyle h(\bm{\theta}_{t})=\sum\nolimits_{k\in\bm{S}_{t}}\theta_{k,t}\frac{{N_{0}Bq_{k}(t)(T_{\max}-T_{k,t}^{\rm{L}})}}{{{h_{k,t}}}}{g_{k}}(\theta_{k,t}). (31)

Problem 𝒫5subscript𝒫5\mathcal{P}_{5} is a standard convex optimization problem, its proof is similar to that for Lemma 3 and thus omitted for brevity. Applying Karush-Kuhn-Tucker condition [29], the optimal solution for 𝜽tsubscript𝜽𝑡\bm{\theta}_{t} satisfies

∂h​(𝜽t)∂θk,t=−λ∗,∀k∈𝑺t,formulae-sequenceℎsubscript𝜽𝑡subscript𝜃𝑘𝑡superscript𝜆for-all𝑘subscript𝑺𝑡\displaystyle\frac{\partial h(\bm{\theta}_{t})}{\partial\theta_{k,t}}=-\lambda^{*},\forall k\in\bm{S}_{t}, (32)

where λ∗superscript𝜆\lambda^{*} is the optimal Lagrange multiply and ∑k∈𝑺tθk,t=1subscript𝑘subscript𝑺𝑡subscript𝜃𝑘𝑡1\sum\nolimits_{k\in\bm{S}_{t}}\theta_{k,t}=1. Thus, for each device k𝑘k, we have

gk​(θk,t)+θk,t​gk′​(θk,t)=−λ∗​hk,tqk​(t)​N0​B​(Tmax−Tk,tL),subscript𝑔𝑘subscript𝜃𝑘𝑡subscript𝜃𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑘′subscript𝜃𝑘𝑡superscript𝜆subscriptℎ𝑘𝑡subscript𝑞𝑘𝑡subscript𝑁0𝐵subscript𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑡L\displaystyle{g_{k}}(\theta_{k,t})+\theta_{k,t}g_{k}^{\prime}(\theta_{k,t})=\frac{{-\lambda^{*}{h_{k,t}}}}{{{q_{k}}(t){N_{0}}B(T_{\max}-T_{k,t}^{\rm{L}})}}, (33)

its inverse function is

θk,t​(λ∗)=Q​ln⁡2B​(Tmax−Tk,tL)​(𝒲​(λ∗​hk,tqk​(t)​N0​B​(Tmax−Tk,tL)​e−1e)+1),subscript𝜃𝑘𝑡superscript𝜆𝑄2𝐵subscript𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑡L𝒲superscript𝜆subscriptℎ𝑘𝑡subscript𝑞𝑘𝑡subscript𝑁0𝐵subscript𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑡L𝑒1𝑒1\displaystyle\theta_{k,t}(\lambda^{*})\!=\!\frac{{Q\ln 2}}{B(T_{\max}\!-\!T_{k,t}^{\rm{L}})\left(\mathcal{W}(\frac{\lambda^{*}h_{k,t}}{q_{k}(t)N_{0}B(T_{\max}\!-\!T_{k,t}^{\rm{L}})e}\!-\!\frac{1}{e})\!+\!1\right)}, (34)

where 𝒲𝒲\mathcal{W} refers to the principal branch of the Lambert 𝒲𝒲\mathcal{W} function, defined as the solution for 𝒲​(x)​e𝒲​(x)=x𝒲𝑥superscript𝑒𝒲𝑥𝑥\mathcal{W}(x)e^{\mathcal{W}(x)}=x, in which e𝑒e refers to the Euler’s number.

In (34), there still exists an unknown variable λ∗superscript𝜆\lambda^{*}. The value of λ∗superscript𝜆\lambda^{*} is determined by the equation ∑k=1Kθk,t​(λ∗)=1superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝜃𝑘𝑡superscript𝜆1\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{K}\theta_{k,t}(\lambda^{*})=1. Since the expression of θk,t​(λ∗)subscript𝜃𝑘𝑡superscript𝜆\theta_{k,t}(\lambda^{*}) is complicated, it is difficult to solve the optimal λ∗superscript𝜆\lambda^{*}. Below we propose a bisection search method to solve ∑k=1Kθk,t​(λ∗)=1superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝜃𝑘𝑡superscript𝜆1\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{K}\theta_{k,t}(\lambda^{*})=1. To proceed, we have the following Proposition.

Proposition 1.

θk,t​(λ)subscript𝜃𝑘𝑡𝜆\theta_{k,t}(\lambda) is a monotonically decreasing function with respect to λ𝜆\lambda.

Proof.

Since the Lagrange multiply λ>0𝜆0\lambda>0, we have λ​hk,te​qk​(t)​N0​B​(Tmax−Tk,tL)−1e>−1e𝜆subscriptℎ𝑘𝑡𝑒subscript𝑞𝑘𝑡subscript𝑁0𝐵subscript𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑡L1𝑒1𝑒\frac{\lambda h_{k,t}}{e{q_{k}}(t)N_{0}B(T_{\max}-T_{k,t}^{\rm{L}})}-\frac{1}{e}>-\frac{1}{e}. Moreover, 𝒲​(x)𝒲𝑥\mathcal{W}(x) is a monotonically increasing function when x≥−1e𝑥1𝑒x\geq-\frac{1}{e}. Thus, θk,t​(λ)subscript𝜃𝑘𝑡𝜆\theta_{k,t}(\lambda) is a monotonically decreasing function with respect to λ𝜆\lambda. ∎

Based on Proposition 1, the bisection search method is employed to solve the equation. In the following, we derive the bisection search upper and lower bound on λ𝜆\lambda. Since λ>0𝜆0\lambda>0, the lower bound of λ𝜆\lambda is λLB=0subscript𝜆LB0\lambda_{\text{LB}}=0. For deriving the upper bound, we have maxk∈𝑺t⁡{θk,t​(λ)}≥1/|𝑺t|subscript𝑘subscript𝑺𝑡subscript𝜃𝑘𝑡𝜆1subscript𝑺𝑡\max_{k\in\bm{S}_{t}}\{\theta_{k,t}(\lambda)\}\geq 1/{|\bm{S}_{t}|}, thus

𝒲​(λ​hk,tqk​(t)​N0​B​(Tmax−Tk,tL)​e−1e)≤|𝑺t|​Q​ln⁡2B​(Tmax−Tk,tL)−1.𝒲𝜆subscriptℎ𝑘𝑡subscript𝑞𝑘𝑡subscript𝑁0𝐵subscript𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑡L𝑒1𝑒subscript𝑺𝑡𝑄2𝐵subscript𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑡L1\displaystyle\mathcal{W}(\frac{\lambda h_{k,t}}{{q_{k}}(t){N_{0}}B(T_{\max}-T_{k,t}^{\rm{L}})e}-\frac{1}{e})\leq\frac{|\bm{S}_{t}|Q\ln 2}{B(T_{\max}-T_{k,t}^{\rm{L}})}-1. (35)

Let φk=|𝑺t|​Q​ln⁡2B​(Tmax−Tk,tL)subscript𝜑𝑘subscript𝑺𝑡𝑄2𝐵subscript𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑡L{\varphi_{k}}=\frac{|\bm{S}_{t}|Q\ln 2}{B(T_{\max}-T_{k,t}^{\rm{L}})}, from the definition of Lambert 𝒲𝒲\mathcal{W} function, we have

λUB=maxk∈𝑺t⁡{qk​(t)​N0​B​(Tmax−Tk,tL)​((φk−1)​eφk+1)hk,t}.subscript𝜆UBsubscript𝑘subscript𝑺𝑡subscript𝑞𝑘𝑡subscript𝑁0𝐵subscript𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑡Lsubscript𝜑𝑘1superscript𝑒subscript𝜑𝑘1subscriptℎ𝑘𝑡\displaystyle\lambda_{\text{UB}}=\max_{k\in\bm{S}_{t}}\left\{\frac{q_{k}(t){N_{0}}B(T_{\max}\!-\!T_{k,t}^{\rm{L}})\left((\varphi_{k}\!-\!1)e^{\varphi_{k}}\!+\!1\right)}{h_{k,t}}\right\}. (36)

According to the lower bound λLBsubscript𝜆LB\lambda_{\text{LB}} and upper bound λUBsubscript𝜆UB\lambda_{\text{UB}}, the optimal Lagrange multiply, λ∗superscript𝜆\lambda^{*}, can be solved by using the bisection search method. Furthermore, the optimal wireless bandwidth allocation policy 𝜽tsubscript𝜽𝑡\bm{\theta}_{t} can be derived from (34). Based on the above analysis, we have the following remark.

Remark 2.

From (32), when the bandwidth allocation policy is optimal, all devices’ energy consumption-bandwidth rates (i.e., ∂h​(𝜽t)∂θk,tℎsubscript𝜽𝑡subscript𝜃𝑘𝑡\frac{\partial h(\bm{\theta}_{t})}{\partial\theta_{k,t}}) are equal. This actual achieves the energy consumption balance between devices. Moreover, similar to the proof of Proposition 1, it can be proved that the optimal bandwidth form in (34) is monotonically decreasing with hk,tsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡h_{k,t} and increasing with qk​(t)subscript𝑞𝑘𝑡q_{k}(t). Thus, more bandwidth should be allocated to the devices with weaker channels (smaller hk,tsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡h_{k,t}) and less remaining energy budgets (larger qk​(t)subscript𝑞𝑘𝑡q_{k}(t)).

IV-C Device Scheduling Policy

Until now, for any given 𝑺tsubscript𝑺𝑡\bm{S}_{t}, the computation time allocation or wireless bandwidth allocation policies can be solved if one of them is fixed. Below we solve the joint computation time and wireless bandwidth allocation policy. For clarity, we formulate the joint computation time allocation and bandwidth allocation problem under given device scheduling decision 𝑺tsubscript𝑺𝑡\bm{S}_{t} as follows:

𝒫6:min{𝜽t,𝑻tL}:subscript𝒫6subscriptsubscript𝜽𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑻𝑡L\displaystyle\mathcal{P}_{6}:\min_{\left\{\bm{\theta}_{t},\bm{T}_{t}^{\rm{L}}\right\}} ∑k∈𝑺tqk​(t)​Ek,tsubscript𝑘subscript𝑺𝑡subscript𝑞𝑘𝑡subscript𝐸𝑘𝑡\displaystyle\sum\nolimits_{k\in\bm{S}_{t}}{q_{k}}(t)E_{k,t} (37)
s. t. (11d),(11e),(22a),11d11e22a\displaystyle(\text{\ref{cons:P_4}}),(\text{\ref{cons:P_5}}),(\text{\ref{cons:P3_1}}),

which is a combination problem of 𝒫4subscript𝒫4\mathcal{P}_{4} and 𝒫5subscript𝒫5\mathcal{P}_{5}. Building on the preceding results, the computation time allocation problem, 𝒫4subscript𝒫4\mathcal{P}_{4}, and the bandwidth allocation problem, 𝒫5subscript𝒫5\mathcal{P}_{5}, are both convex optimization problems, problem 𝒫6subscript𝒫6\mathcal{P}_{6} is also a convex optimization problem. Thus, we solve the joint computation time and wireless bandwidth allocation policies via iterations [30] between problem 𝒫4subscript𝒫4\mathcal{P}_{4} and problem 𝒫5subscript𝒫5\mathcal{P}_{5}. Each iteration consists of two steps: (1) solving the optimal solution of problem 𝒫5subscript𝒫5\mathcal{P}_{5} for given 𝑻tLsuperscriptsubscript𝑻𝑡L\bm{T}_{t}^{\rm{L}}; (2) solving the computation time allocation policy 𝑻tLsuperscriptsubscript𝑻𝑡L\bm{T}_{t}^{\rm{L}} based on the obtained bandwidth allocation solution 𝜽tsubscript𝜽𝑡\bm{\theta}_{t}. The two steps are iterated until convergence. For clarity, we summarize the detailed steps on joint optimization of computation time and wireless bandwidth in Algorithm 1. Based on the complexity analysis results in [30], the time complexity of Algorithm 1 is 𝒪​(2​K3.5)𝒪2superscript𝐾3.5\mathcal{O}(2K^{3.5}).

Through the above analysis, we can solve the optimal value of the objective function in (22) for any given device scheduling decision 𝑺tsubscript𝑺𝑡\bm{S}_{t}. An intuitive method to solve the optimal device scheduling solution is to solve the objective function value of all the possible device scheduling decisions first and then select the one with the minimum objective function value. However, this method has exponential time complexity 𝒪​(K3.5×2K+1)𝒪superscript𝐾3.5superscript2𝐾1\mathcal{O}(K^{3.5}\times 2^{K+1}) since there are total ∑n=0KCKn=2Ksuperscriptsubscript𝑛0𝐾superscriptsubscript𝐶𝐾𝑛superscript2𝐾\sum_{n=0}^{K}C_{K}^{n}=2^{K} possible device scheduling decisions. To tackle this challenge, we have the following designs.

According to the objective function (22), it is desirable to select devices with small qk​(t)subscript𝑞𝑘𝑡q_{k}(t) and Ek,tsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑡E_{k,t}. The small Ek,tsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑡E_{k,t} can be achieved by strong channels or/and high computation efficiencies. To identify such devices, we first perform equal bandwidth allocation over all devices and then evaluate the resulting energy consumption of each device E¯k,tsubscript¯𝐸𝑘𝑡\bar{E}_{k,t}. Specifically, each device k𝑘k is allocated the same portion, θk,t=1Ksubscript𝜃𝑘𝑡1𝐾\theta_{k,t}=\frac{1}{K}, of the total bandwidth B𝐵B, and then solve problem 𝒫4subscript𝒫4\mathcal{P}_{4} to obtain the computation time allocation policy 𝑻tLsuperscriptsubscript𝑻𝑡L\bm{T}_{t}^{\rm{L}}. Then, by substituting θk,t=1Ksubscript𝜃𝑘𝑡1𝐾\theta_{k,t}=\frac{1}{K} and 𝑻tLsuperscriptsubscript𝑻𝑡L\bm{T}_{t}^{\rm{L}} into the (7) and (21), the estimated energy consumption is calculated as E¯k,t=Ek,tU+Ek,tLsubscript¯𝐸𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑡Usuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑡L\bar{E}_{k,t}=E_{k,t}^{\rm{U}}+E_{k,t}^{\rm{L}}.

Based on the evaluated energy consumption E¯k,tsubscript¯𝐸𝑘𝑡\bar{E}_{k,t}, we sort 𝒞k,t=qk​(t)​E¯k,tsubscript𝒞𝑘𝑡subscript𝑞𝑘𝑡subscript¯𝐸𝑘𝑡\mathcal{C}_{k,t}=q_{k}(t)\bar{E}_{k,t} in the ascending order, and then use the set expansion algorithm [12] to solve the device selection policy by incrementally adds devices into the selection set, S𝑆S. Firstly, the devices with qk​(t)=0subscript𝑞𝑘𝑡0q_{k}(t)=0 are all added into S𝑆S, denote this device set by S0subscript𝑆0S_{0}. Next, the devices with qk​(t)>0subscript𝑞𝑘𝑡0q_{k}(t)>0 are added into S𝑆S one by one in the ascending order of 𝒞k,tsubscript𝒞𝑘𝑡\mathcal{C}_{k,t}. For each possible device scheduling set S𝑆S, we perform Algorithm 1 to obtain the computation time and wireless bandwidth allocation decisions. Let ℛ∗​(S)=(θ∗​(S),T∗​(S))superscriptℛ𝑆superscript𝜃𝑆superscript𝑇𝑆\mathcal{R}^{*}(S)=(\theta^{*}(S),T^{*}(S)) denote the time and wireless bandwidth decision and 𝒴​(S)𝒴𝑆\mathcal{Y}(S) represent the corresponding objective function value of S𝑆S, respectively. Denote ℋℋ\mathcal{H} as the set of all possible device scheduling set S𝑆S.

Note that, 𝒴​(S0)=−V​∑k∈S0Dk𝒴subscript𝑆0𝑉subscript𝑘subscript𝑆0subscript𝐷𝑘\mathcal{Y}(S_{0})=-V\sum\nolimits_{k\in S_{0}}D_{k} due to qk​(t)=0subscript𝑞𝑘𝑡0q_{k}(t)=0 (∀k∈S0for-all𝑘subscript𝑆0\forall k\in S_{0}). Since the energy consumption of users in S0subscript𝑆0S_{0} does not affect the objective function value, the minimum required bandwidth should be allocated to them for saving more bandwidth resources for other users in (S−S0)𝑆subscript𝑆0(S-S_{0}). Moreover, we add the users with qk​(t)>0subscript𝑞𝑘𝑡0q_{k}(t)>0 one by one into S𝑆S and solve the ℛ∗​(S)superscriptℛ𝑆\mathcal{R}^{*}(S) and 𝒴​(S)𝒴𝑆\mathcal{Y}(S). For S𝑆S, if its optimal computation time and wireless bandwidth allocation policy results in −V​Dk+qk​(t)​Ek,t>0𝑉subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝑞𝑘𝑡subscript𝐸𝑘𝑡0-VD_{k}+q_{k}(t)E_{k,t}>0 for the last added device k𝑘k, we stop adding devices into S𝑆S and remove the last added device. Then, we obtain the device scheduling policy through comparing the objective function value of all S∈ℋ𝑆ℋS\in\mathcal{H}, i.e., St∗=arg​minS∈ℋ⁡𝒴​(S)superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑡subscriptargmin𝑆ℋ𝒴𝑆S_{t}^{*}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{S\in\mathcal{H}}\mathcal{Y}(S). The computation time and optimal bandwidth allocation policy correspond to Tt∗​(S)superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑡𝑆T_{t}^{*}(S) and θt∗​(S)superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑆\theta_{t}^{*}(S). For clarity, we summarize the detail steps of device scheduling in Algorithm 2, which obtains the device scheduling solution of problem 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1} by solving at most K𝐾K times convex problem 𝒫6subscript𝒫6\mathcal{P}_{6} and has polynomial time complexity 𝒪​(2​K4.5)𝒪2superscript𝐾4.5\mathcal{O}(2K^{4.5}) , which is smaller than O​(K3.5×2K+1)𝑂superscript𝐾3.5superscript2𝐾1O(K^{3.5}\times 2^{K+1}) when K>1𝐾1K>1.

V Numerical Results

In this section, we evaluate the performance of the proposed energy-efficient dynamic device scheduling FL algorithm. In the simulation, all the codes are implemented in python 3.8 and Pytorch, running on a Linux server. We first present the evaluation setup and then show experimental results.

V-A Experimental Setting

The default experiment settings are given as follows unless specified otherwise.

  1. 1)

    Datasets and Models: We evaluate the proposed algorithm for an image classification task using MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets. The MNIST dataset consists of 60,000 and 10,000 grey-valued digital images for training and test, respectively. Each image is a handwritten digital between 0 and 9 displayed as a 28×\times28 pixel matrix. The CIFAR-10 dataset consists of 60000 32×\times32 colour images in 10 classes, with 50000 training images and 10000 test images. For both MNIST and CIFAR-10, we first classify the training data samples according to their labels, then randomly split each class of data samples into 2​K/102𝐾102K/10 shards, finally randomly distribute two shards of data samples to each device. For the MNIST dataset, we train a MLP, which consists of 4 layers with 550346 parameters in total. The first four layers have 784, 512, 256, and 64 units, respectively. Each of these layers is activated by the ReLU function. The last layer is a 10-unit softmax output layer. For the MLP, the number of FLOPs required to one data sample for gradient calculation is equal to its parameters’ number. In our proposed FL approach, devices only share parameters of the first 2 layers, which has 533504 parameters, accounting for 96.7% of the entire model parameters. For the CIFAR-10 dataset, we train a CNN with the following structure: two 5×5555\times 5 convolution layers each with 64 channels and followed by a 2×2222\times 2 max-pooling layer; three fully connected layers with 1600, 120, and 64 units, respectively; and a 10-unit softmax output layer. Each convolution or fully connected layer is activated by the ReLU function. The CNN possesses 307842 parameters and our proposed FL approach only share the first 4 layers in the training process, which has 99.7% of the total number of model parameters. For both MLP and CNN, the learning rate ηusubscript𝜂𝑢\eta_{u} and ηvsubscript𝜂𝑣\eta_{v} are set to 0.05, a momentum of 0.9 is adopted, the number of local iterations is set to 5, each parameter is quantitated as 16 bits, and cross entropy is adopted as the loss function.

  2. 2)

    System setting: If not specified, the system parameters related to communication and computation are set as follows. We consider that K=100𝐾100K=100 devices are randomly distributed within a 500m ×\times 500m single cell with total bandwidth B=10𝐵10B=10 MHz, and the PS is located in the cell’s centre. The channel noise power spectral density N0subscript𝑁0N_{0} is set to −174174-174 dBm. For all devices in the system, we set their maximum transmit power and CPU frequency as fk,max=1subscript𝑓𝑘1f_{k,\max}=1GHz and pk,max=1subscript𝑝𝑘1p_{k,\max}=1W, respectively. Similar to [24, 31], we set the energy coefficient κ=5×10−27𝜅5superscript1027\kappa=5\times 10^{-27}. The channel gain is modeled as hk,t=h0​ρk​(t)​(d0/dk)vsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡subscriptℎ0subscript𝜌𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑑0subscript𝑑𝑘𝑣h_{k,t}=h_{0}{\rho_{k}}(t)(d_{0}/d_{k})^{v}, where h0=−30subscriptℎ030h_{0}=-30dB is the path loss constant; dksubscript𝑑𝑘d_{k} is the distance between device k𝑘k and the PS; d0=1subscript𝑑01d_{0}=1m is the reference distance; ρk​(t)∼Exp​(1)similar-tosubscript𝜌𝑘𝑡Exp1\rho_{k}(t)\sim\text{Exp}(1) is exponentially distributed with unit mean, which represents the small-scale fading channel power gain from the device k𝑘k to the PS in round t𝑡t; d0/dksubscript𝑑0subscript𝑑𝑘d_{0}/d_{k} represents the large-scale path loss with v=2𝑣2v=2 being the path loss exponent. Besides, we set Tmax=2subscript𝑇2T_{\max}=2s and E¯k=0.1subscript¯𝐸𝑘0.1\bar{E}_{k}=0.1J for the MNIST dataset, and Tmax=14subscript𝑇14T_{\max}=14s and E¯k=2subscript¯𝐸𝑘2\bar{E}_{k}=2J for the CIFAR-10 dataset.

V-B Performance of Partial Model Parameters Aggregation

To verify the advantages of the proposed PMA-FL algorithm, we compare its performance with three benchmarks. 1) Regularized FL [18]: Regularized FL uses a proximal term to regularize each local loss function for tackling the data heterogeneity. 2) FedAvg [19]: The selected devices upload the entire model to the PS for aggregation in each round. 3) FedRep [22]: In each round, the selected devices sequentially train the feature extractor and predictor. After local training, the selected devices upload their feature extractors for aggregation. Actually, Regularized FL and FedAvg requires more computation and bandwidth resources than the proposed approach. Note that, we do not consider the energy and bandwidth limitation in this subsection.

Fig. 3 compares the performance of the proposed approach with two benchmarks on the MNIST dataset. It is observed that the proposed FL approach outperforms the benchmarks in terms of test accuracy and test loss. Specifically, the proposed approach boosts 3.13% when |𝑺t|=10subscript𝑺𝑡10\left|\bm{S}_{t}\right|=10 and 0.79% accuracy when |𝑺t|=50subscript𝑺𝑡50\left|\bm{S}_{t}\right|=50 compared with the benchmark approaches. Moreover, the proposed approach converges faster than the benchmarks. Note that the convergence point in 3 and 3 are defined as the first point that the variation of test accuracy and loss value is less than 10−6superscript10610^{-6}, respectively. Additionally, compared with the three benchmarks, the proposed approach is less sensitive to the fraction of participating devices in each round. After 40 global rounds, the proposed approach with 10 devices participating in each round can obtain a similar performance as 50 devices participating in each round. The device participating ratio only affects the convergence speed and almost without reducing the final accuracy. However, the benchmarks are sensitive for the fraction of participating devices in each round, especially the training processes of Regularized FL and FedAvg are unstable when the participating ratio of devices is small, like 10 devices.

Fig. 4 presents the performance of the proposed approach and two benchmarks on the CIFAR-10 datasets, drawing a similar conclusion with the experiments on the MNIST dataset. In particular, the proposed approach obtained a more distinct performance improvement on this more complicate dataset, boosting 11.8% and 3.3% accuracy than the benchmark schemes when |𝑺t|=10subscript𝑺𝑡10\left|\bm{S}_{t}\right|=10 and |𝑺t|=50subscript𝑺𝑡50\left|\bm{S}_{t}\right|=50, respectively. Similarly, the learning processes of Regularized FL and FedAvg is unstable when a small fraction of devices participate in each round, i.e., |𝑺t|=10subscript𝑺𝑡10\left|\bm{S}_{t}\right|=10. These results indicate that the proposed approach is more robust, performing well in real datasets.

V-C Performance of the Proposed Energy-Efficient Device Scheduling Algorithm

In this subsection, we verify the effectiveness of the proposed dynamic device scheduling algorithm by comparing it with the following device scheduling schemes. For fairness, we use these benchmark schemes to schedule devices for the proposed FL approach instead of their original FedAvg approach. Each curve is averaged over 100 and 50 runs for MNIST and CIFAR-10, respectively.

  1. 1)

    Random scheduling without energy limitation (RS-WEL): Devices do not have energy limitation while the bandwidth and delay constraints exist. In each round, RS-WEL uses the set expansion algorithm to schedule devices. Specifically, it incrementally adds devices (randomly selected from all devices without replacement) into the scheduling set until violating the bandwidth constraint. Then, the last scheduling set that satisfies bandwidth constraints is the true scheduling device set.

  2. 2)

    OCEAN[12]: The OCEAN is also a Lyapunov optimization-based device scheduling approach, in which the spectral bandwidth is orthogonally allocated to the scheduled devices for global aggregation in each communication round.

Based on the MNIST dataset, Fig. 5 shows the effect of devices’ energy budget on the training performance of the proposed dynamic device scheduling algorithm and two benchmarks. The results indicate that our proposed dynamic device scheduling algorithm outperforms the two benchmarks. Given the same energy budget, i.e., E¯k=0.14subscript¯𝐸𝑘0.14\bar{E}_{k}=0.14J, the proposed algorithm achieves 3.28% test accuracy improvement comparing with the OCEAN algorithm. Moreover, the proposed algorithm is able to obtain better performance than the OCEAN algorithm under less energy budget. Specifically, the proposed algorithm with energy budget E¯k=0.1subscript¯𝐸𝑘0.1\bar{E}_{k}=0.1J (71% of the energy budget of OCEAN) remains improving 2.59% accuracy compared to the OCEAN algorithm with energy budget E¯k=0.14subscript¯𝐸𝑘0.14\bar{E}_{k}=0.14J. Compared with the RS-WEL scheme with unlimited energy budget, the proposed algorithm achieves a slight accuracy improvement when the energy budget is E¯k=0.14subscript¯𝐸𝑘0.14\bar{E}_{k}=0.14J.

A similar evaluation is made on the CIFAR-10 dataset in Fig. 5. Given energy budget E¯k=4subscript¯𝐸𝑘4\bar{E}_{k}=4J for both the proposed algorithm and the OCEAN algorithm, the proposed algorithm achieves around a 1.85% accuracy boosts for the OCEAN algorithm. Similarly, the proposed algorithm under 75% energy budget (E¯k=3subscript¯𝐸𝑘3\bar{E}_{k}=3J) outperforms the OCEAN algorithm with an energy budget E¯k=4subscript¯𝐸𝑘4\bar{E}_{k}=4J, obtaining 1.25% accuracy gain. Additionally, the proposed algorithm with E¯k=2subscript¯𝐸𝑘2\bar{E}_{k}=2J obtains a similar performance as the OCEAN algorithm with E¯k=4subscript¯𝐸𝑘4\bar{E}_{k}=4J and the RS-WEL scheme. The performance gain mainly comes from the joint optimization for both computation and wireless resources. In our proposed algorithm, the participating devices can get a trade-off between computation and communication energy consumption, achieving the most energy-efficient learning process. Specifically, the devices with poor channel conditions can boost their CPU frequency for reducing computation time and thus reserve more time for wireless communications. In contrast, devices with good channel conditions can lower the CPU frequency to balance computation and communication energy consumption.

We compare our proposed device scheduling algorithm with the benchmarks under different latency constraints on MNIST dataset in Fig. 6. Clearly, as the latency constraint, Tmaxsubscript𝑇T_{\max}, increases, the learning performance is improved. This is because a larger Tmaxsubscript𝑇T_{\max} helps save the computation and communication energy and thus more data samples are able to scheduled in each round. Moreover, with the same latency constraints, i.e., Tmax=2.5subscript𝑇2.5T_{\max}=2.5s, the proposed algorithm boosts 3.45% test accuracy compared with the OCEAN algorithm. Using the RS-WEL as the baseline, the proposed algorithm obtains a minor accuracy gain. One interesting phenomenon is that the proposed algorithm outperforms the OCEAN algorithm with a stricter delay restriction. Specifically, given time budget Tmax=2subscript𝑇2T_{\max}=2s for the proposed algorithm, it obtains 2.3% accuracy gain than the OCEAN algorithm with Tmax=2.5subscript𝑇2.5T_{\max}=2.5s. In other words, the proposed algorithm is able to obtain a better accuracy with a 20% time budget reduction. Although the proposed algorithm with Tmax=1.5subscript𝑇1.5T_{\max}=1.5s performs not good as the OCEAN algorithm with Tmax=2.5subscript𝑇2.5T_{\max}=2.5s, the above results illustrate it has the ability to improve accuracy with a stringent delay.

Fig. 6 shows the impact of time budget on CIFAR-10 dataset, obtaining a similar results on the MNIST dataset. Specifically, the proposed algorithm boosts 2.17% test accuracy with the OCEAN algorithm under same delay restriction Tmax=16subscript𝑇16T_{\max}=16s. Compared with the RS-WEL scheme, the proposed algorithm gains 0.75% performance improvement with Tmax=16subscript𝑇16T_{\max}=16s, and obtains a similar performance with Tmax=14subscript𝑇14T_{\max}=14s. Moreover, under a stringent delay requirement, i.e., Tmax=14subscript𝑇14T_{\max}=14s, the proposed algorithm achieves a better performance than the OCEAN algorithm with Tmax=16subscript𝑇16T_{\max}=16s. That is, the proposed algorithm is able to get a better performance as the OCEAN algorithm with 12.5% time budget reduction. The underlying reason is that the joint optimization of computation and communication achieves lower energy consumption than solely considering the optimal communication. Even with less time budget, the balance between computation and communication can also lower the overall energy consumption, enabling more devices to participate in the FL training process in a sustainable way.

In Fig. 7, we verify that the adjustable weight parameter V𝑉V is able to balance the training performance and energy consumption of devices. Fig. 7 shows that as V𝑉V increases, devices consume energy in a more aggressive manner, resulting in scheduling more data samples, thus obtaining accuracy improvement. From Fig. 7, the experiments on the MNIST dataset indicate that the proposed algorithm achieves 3.46%, 1.94%, and 0.63% test accuracy improvement compared with the OCEAN algorithm under V=0.001𝑉0.001V=0.001, V=0.01𝑉0.01V=0.01, and V=0.1𝑉0.1V=0.1, in each one respectively. Interestingly, the proposed algorithm with V=0.001𝑉0.001V=0.001 obtains a similar performance with the OCEAN algorithm with V=0.01𝑉0.01V=0.01. This further reveals that the proposed algorithm has the ability to obtain a similar performance as the OCEAN algorithm under a more rigid energy restriction. Similarly, on the CIFAR-10 dataset, the proposed algorithm boosts 1.05% and 1.23% accuracy in terms of V=0.001𝑉0.001V=0.001 and V=0.01𝑉0.01V=0.01, and obtains a slight accuracy improvement when V=0.1𝑉0.1V=0.1 compared with the OCEAN algorithm. Note that, if V𝑉V is too large, the device scheduling algorithm would pay less attention for devices’ energy consumption and try to schedule more devices. This may break the energy budget limitation for devices. Thus, the value of V𝑉V should be judiciously adjusted to optimize the training performance while satisfying the long-term energy constraints.

VI Conclusion

In this work, we have proposed a novel PMA-FL algorithm, which only shares the feature extractor part of neural networks for global aggregation in the learning process while the predictor part of each device is localized for personalization. This design effectively improves the robustness and performance of the training process, overcoming the data heterogeneity across devices. Experiments show that PMA-FL is able to boost 3.13% and 11.8% accuracy on MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets compared to the benchmark approaches, respectively. In addition, we have theoretically analyzed the convergence bound of PMA-FL with a general non-convex loss function setting. To implement the PMA-FL in resource-limited wireless networks, we have devised a joint device scheduling, communication and computation resource allocation approach to improve the learning performance by achieving the energy consumption balance between communication and computation for each device and the energy consumption-bandwidth balance between devices. Compared with the considered benchmarks with the same energy and time budgets, PMA-FL obtained around 3% and 2% accuracy improvement on the MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets, respectively. Moreover, PMA-FL is able to obtain slightly higher accuracy than the benchmarks with 29% energy or 20% time reduction on the MNIST; and 25% energy or 12.5% time reduction on the CIFAR-10.
